official-title.#text:
Expressing the sense of the House of Representatives regarding the President’s responsibility to
			 address the border crisis.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that there is an

quote.#text:
actual humanitarian crisis on the border that only underscores the need to drop the politics and
			 fix our immigration system once and for all

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to use the resources already at his disposal to gain certifiable
			 operational control of the border;

to send a clear message that those who are seeking to enter the United
			 States illegally will be returned to their home countries;

to send a clear message that subjecting children to the perilous migration
			 northward to our border will no longer be tolerated;

to cease using his prosecutorial discretion authority to shield unlawful
			 immigrants from prosecution;
to cease releasing convicted criminal aliens from detention;
to crack down on fraudulent asylum claims;
to implement tougher standards for

to restore agreements with local law enforcement agencies to enforce
			 immigration laws;
to give

agents access to Federal lands where drug
			 traffickers, human smugglers, and unlawful immigrants hide;

to employ diplomatic resources with Mexico, Honduras, Guatemala, and El
			 Salvador to stop the border crisis; and

to make certain the preceding calls to action are realized
			 as expeditiously as possible.

text.#text:
Whereas the El Paso Intelligence Center (EPIC), a highly respected intelligence analysis center in
			 support of field enforcement entities throughout the Southwest border
			 region, was established in 1974 and contains representatives from 24
			 agencies;

Whereas the EPIC intelligence report from July 7, 2014, assessed homicide trends in Central
			 American countries and migrant interviews, suggesting violence is likely
			 not the principal factor driving the increase in unlawful migration into
			 the United States;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
interviewed unaccompanied minors and migrant families
			 apprehended in the Rio Grande Valley, and of the 230 total unlawful
			 immigrants interviewed, 95 percent (219 individuals) cited the primary
			 reason for migrating to the United States was the perception of United
			 States immigration laws granting free passes or permisos allowing them to
			 stay;

Whereas the EPIC intelligence report from July 7, 2014, reveals several United States media outlets
			 have identified Central American newspapers that have enticed children to
			 travel to the United States, including Honduran and El Salvadoran press
			 which have reportedly advertised the DACA policy, accommodations for
			 detained unlawful immigrants, and the promise of reunification with family
			 members in the United States;
